Award.AbstractNarration:
This CISE Special Projects award funds student support to participate in the first Networking Networking Women (N^2Women) Workshop. The workshop will be co-located with the 16th Annual International Conference on Mobile Computing and Networking (MobiCom 2010) and the 11th ACM International Symposium on Mobile Ad Hoc Networking and Computing (MobiHoc 2010. The N^2 Women workshop is scheduled to occur the day before the conferences allowing workshop participants to form connections that can be strengthened during the conferences. The purpose of the N^2 Women Workshop is to foster connections among the under-represented women in the communications and networking research fields. The N^2 Women workshop will be a one day event to provide networking researchers the opportunity to showcase their work and make connections with others. It will include participants from the industrial, governmental, and academic sectors and offer students an excellent opportunity to learn about emerging research topics and to get connected with others in the networking community.

The intellectual merit of the project resides in the contributions that the student participants will make to the N^2Women Workshop and the two associated conferences as well as the impact on the future scientific progress of the students' research. The exposure to the research-based technical content will inspire students to address the tough problems in their respective fields, with a potential for a long-term benefit of scientific progress for networking research.

The broader impacts of the project revolve around the development of the under-represented graduate students who are able to participate in the coordinated events through this travel support. The funds will allow the students to attend high-caliber technical presentations, be exposed to state-of-the-art research, and interact with leading researchers and fellow graduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of Networking Networking Women (N2Women) community is to foster connections among the under-represented women in the communications and networking research fields. There are currently 450+ members of N2Women from around the world. Since May 2006 (when the N2Women community was started), over 40 N2Women meetings have been organized at a number of prestigious ACM and IEEE research conferences. In 2008, N2Women members were surveyed and 98.8% said they would be interested in attending a much longer gathering than what is possible via an N2Women meeting. Thus, the 1st Networking Networking Women Workshop was organized. 

NSF provided funding to support students at U.S. institutions to attend this 1st Networking Networking Women Workshop, which occurred on September 20, 2010 in Chicago, Illinois in conjunction with (1) the 16th Annual International Conference on Mobile Computing and Networking (MobiCom 2010) and (2) the 11th ACM International Symposium on Mobile Ad Hoc Networking and Computing (MobiHoc 2010). The 2010 MobiCom conference received 233 paper submissions and accepted 33 (14.16% acceptance rate). The 2010 MobiHoc conference received 154 paper submissions and accepted 26 (16.88% acceptance rate). These two acceptance ratios indicate that MobiCom and MobiHoc provide an outstanding technical program in the mobile communication and wireless ad hoc networking fields. Thus, the N2Women Workshop organizers wanted to co-locate their workshop with these two prestigious events. 

Currently 481 women are members of N2Women, and 65 of them attended this workshop representing the following countries: Canada, France, India, Spain, Sweden, and Switzerland. We advertised the availability of these travel grants on both the N2Women mailing list and on the MobiCom/Hoc web site (in conjunction with the support available for students to attend the MobiCom/Hoc conferences).  To apply for a travel grant, a student had to submit a curriculum vita, a short personal statement (maximum one page), and a supporting letter from the student’s advisor. The student’s short personal statement included an overview of the student’s research interests/accomplishments and a description of how attending the workshop/conference would be beneficial to the student’s career. The supporting letter from the student’s advisor included confirmation that the student was in good academic standing within the student’s Ph.D. program, as well as any benefits the advisor expected the student to receive from attending the co-located events.

A small travel grants committee, which was chaired by Yingying Chen at Stevens Institute of Technology and Sami Rollins at University of San Francisco, reviewed all the applications. The committee members then ranked the applications for awarding support; the chairs then worked with the PI to make final decisions. 86 students applied for travel support, and 25 of them were awarded funding from this project. 

The intellectual merit of this project resided in the contributions that the student participants made to (1) the N2Women Workshop, (2) the MobiCom/Hoc 2010 event (premier conferences in their respective mobile computing fields) and (3) the future scientific progress of the student's research. The exposure to the technical content of both the N2Women Workshop and the MobiCom/Hoc 2010 conferences inspired students to address the tough problems in their respective field. 

The broader impact of this project concerned the development of the graduate students that were able to attend the N2Women Workshop (and perhaps the MobiCom/Hoc 2010 conference as well) due to the provided travel support.
